questions.text:
A 48-year-old man, who works in a mortuary was caught by the police while obtaining sexual gratification with a corpse. He is punishable under

IPC - Indian Penal Code, BNS- Bharatiya Nayaya Sanhita
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a man obtaining sexual gratification with dead bodies describes necrophilia. Necrophilia is punishable under Sec 301 BNS (297 IPC).

It deals with a punishment of imprisonment of up to 1 year and/or a fine for both necrophilia and necrophagia.

Necrophilia describes a person who obtains sexual gratification by intercourse with dead bodies. Necrophagia describes a person who sucks the wound, bites the skin, sucks the blood, and eats the flesh of a dead body to derive sexual pleasure.

Other options:

Option A: Sec 292 BNS (290 IPC) - Punishment for frotteurism with fine up to Rs. 1000.

Option B: Sec 296 BNS (294 IPC) - Punishment for exhibitionism with imprisonment of up to 3 months or a fine. 

Option D: Sec 101 BNS (300 IPC) - Definition of murder.

questions.text: “Motorcyclist’s fracture” is which of the following

choices.text: Ring fracture of base of skull
Hinge fracture of base of skull

questions.solution:
Motorcyclist's fracture is Hinge fracture of the base of skull in which base of skull is divided into 2 halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge.

Option b- ring fracture
Falls from a height onto the top of the skull or onto the feet, where the force is transmitted to the base of the skull through the spine, may result in ring fracture of the base of the skull around the foramen magnum

Option c- comminuted fracture
Comminuted fractures are those in which the bone shatters into multiple pieces.
They are commonly seen with the use of heavy weapon with broad striking surface and in vehicle and railway accidents.

Option d – depressed fracture
Depressed fractures will force fragments of skull inwards. Blows to the head by implements, like round-headed hammers, may cause depressed vault fractures.

questions.text: Gettler’s test is positive in:
questions.solution:
Gettler test is done for drowning. It estimates the chloride content of blood from both sides of the heart.

Normally, chloride content is equal in the right and left chambers of the heart (approx. 600 mg/100 ml). In freshwater drowning, due to hemodilution, the chloride content is decreased on the left side of the heart by 50%. In saltwater drowning due to hemoconcentration, the chloride content is increased in the left side of the heart by 30-40%.

This test is said to be negative in post-mortem drowning. 

Limitations of the test:

No value in atypical drowning, or congenital cardiac defects, if the drowning medium contains the same amount of chloride. There is a progressive loss of chlorine from blood after death. Therefore, the test has to be made within a reasonably short time after death.

Drowning:

Drowning is the process of experiencing respiratory impairment from submersion/immersion in liquid. Accidental drowning is the most common form of drowning, seen among fishermen, bathers, dock workers, intoxicated, and epileptics.

Pathophysiology:

In cases of seawater drowning, hypernatremia and myocardial anoxia are seen. Seawater being hypertonic to plasma causes a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing hemoconcentration and a fall in blood pressure.

This hemoconcentration in seawater drowning causes increased viscosity of blood and myocardial anoxia leading to heart failure. Hyperkalemia is not seen in seawater drowning because RBCs get shrunken in contrast to freshwater drowning.

Freshwater is hypotonic to plasma and is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli into the RBCs resulting in hemodilution and hyponatremia. The RBCs finally swell up and lyse resulting in the release of intracellular potassium causing hyperkalemia. Increased intravascular blood volume combined with hyperkalemia causes arrhythmia.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed or when sectioned with a knife. 
  • Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs.
  • Paltauf’s spots - Subpleural hemorrhages due to rupture of alveolar walls
  • Dilation of the right heart and great veins - This is a very subjective and non-specific finding.
  • Foreign material in the stomach - The stomach may contain watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed, or sand. 
  • Hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - This has been postulated as a positive sign of drowning, but it is a non-specific finding.
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses - Also not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning.

Thus, the autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. The most useful one is froth in the air passages.

questions.text: Induction of MTP is not allowed unless for serious maternal causes when the period of gestation exceeds
questions.solution:
According to the MTP Amendment Act 2021, induction of MTP is allowed up to 24 weeks of gestation unless for serious maternal causes. In case of serious causes (substantial fetal anomalies), it is allowed only with the approval of the medical board.

Pregnancy below 20 weeks can be terminated on the opinion of a single doctor.

Between 20 to 24 weeks, two doctors must agree that there is an indication.

In an emergency, MTP can be done by a single doctor even after 20 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: All of the following are tests to check cessation of circulation except
questions.solution:
Magnus’s test (ligature test), Diaphanous test (Transillumination test), Icard’s test, Fingernail test are tests to check cessation of circulation. Option b: Winslow’s test is used to check cessation of respiration.

Tests for confirming cessation of circulation: No audible heart sounds on continuous auscultation on precordial area of chest for a minimum of 5 minutes, is suggestive of cessation of circulation and a flat ECG recording for 5 minutes confirms this.

Other tests:

  • Magnus’s test (Ligature test)—fingers fail to show congestion distal to a ligature applied at their base.
  • Diaphanous test (Transillumination test)—Failure to show redness in the web space between the fingers on transillumination from behind.
  • Icard’s test—fluorescent dye on being injected at a given site in a dead body fails to produces any discolouration.
  • Fingernail test—no blanching and filling of blood in the fingernail on application of pressure and release.

questions.text: The crown heel length of a 6-month-old fetus would likely be:
questions.solution:
According to Haase's modification of Morisson's law, the Age of the fetus during the last 5 months of pregnancy = Crown heel length(in cm)/5. So, crown heel length = age in months × 5 i.e. 6 × 5 = 30cm. Therefore, the crown heel length of a 6-month-old fetus is 30cm.

Rule of Haase: A rough method of calculating the age of the fetus. The length of the fetus is measured from the crown to the hell in centimeters. During the first five months of pregnancy, the square root of the length gives the approximate age of the fetus in months. E.g., a fetus of 16cm is four months old.

questions.text: A bullet that follows the following trajectory in its path is a
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bullet that rotates end-to-end during its motion and it is called a tumbling bullet.

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: A man who had a fistfight with a neighbor was brought to you with a fracture of the lower central incisor and soft tissue injury to the area around his mouth. He also had contusions on his legs. What is the nature of this injury?
questions.solution:
Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth is categorized as grievous injury.

Grievous hurt is inflicted voluntarily to another person and comprise of any of the eight kinds (clauses) enumerated below:

  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 15 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Grievous hurt is a cognizable offence for which a police officer can arrest a person without a warrant from magistrate. (BNS Sec 116/320 IPC)

Punishment for grievous hurt :

  • BNS Sec 117(2): Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt –imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
  • BNS Sec 118(2) Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means—minimum imprisonment of 1 year, extendable up to 10 years and fine.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought for medical examination by her parents, with complaints of being sexually assaulted by her neighbor. What would be the likely hymenal finding in this child?

choices.text: Ruptured since it is superficially situated
Ruptured since it is very thin
Unruptured since it is deeply situated
Unruptured since it is highly elastic

questions.solution:
In this child, the hymen is likely to be unruptured since it is deeply situated and usually intact after intercourse.

 As the vagina is very small, it is impossible for the penetration of the adult organ to take place. In children, there are few or no signs of general   violence, as the child is unaware of the assault and incapable of resisting.

 The penis is usually placed within the vulva and between the thighs. Forceful penetration may cause the penis to be pushed backward by the   symphysis pubis, and the hymen may be torn posteriorly.

 A few indicators for routine enquiry are pain on urination and/or defecation, abdominal pain, inability to sleep, sudden withdrawal from peers/adults,   feelings of anxiety, nervousness, helplessness, weight loss, and feelings of ending one’s life.

 On examination, blood may be oozing from the injured parts or blood clots may be found. An attempt to separate the thighs may cause pain. The child    may walk with difficulty due to the pain. The labia majora may be contused, abraded, or lacerated. Circumferential tears may be seen in children        up  to six years.

questions.text: Given below is an image of Spanish windlass. What type of execution is it
questions.solution:
Spanish windlass is a type of garrotting.

It used to be the official mode of execution in Spain. In this, an iron collar around the neck was tightened by a screw for strangulation.

Garotting is used in lonely places to kill and rob travelers, where the victim is attacked from behind without warning. The throat may be grasped or a ligature is thrown over the neck and quickly tightened resulting in sudden loss of consciousness and collapse. In this way a single assailant can kill a healthy adult male.

SEM – EDXA

  • It is the most sophisticated tool to examine minute traces of gunshot residue.
  • Gunshot residue comprises of gases, metals like antimony, Barium, Copper deposited on hands, face, cloths of suspect.

  • Tests the presence of Antimony, Barium, copper.

  • Aids in :

    • Determining Range of fire.
    • Determining common origin of bullet fragments.

Neutron Activation analysis

  • It is the chemical analysis of antimony and copper.
  • Based on characteristic radioisotopes formed by irradiation of elements.

questions.text: ‘Charas’ is
questions.solution:
Resin exuding from the leaves and stems of the Cannabis indica plant is known as Charas.

Charas:

  • It is also called as Hashish.
  • It is the purest form of cannabis obtained from resin of Cannabis indica.
  • It is the resin (dope or shit) exuding from the leaves and stems of the plant.
  • It is dark green or brown in colour, and contains 25 to 40 per cent of the active principle.
  • This is also mixed with tobacco and used to smoke by a pipe or hookah.

Cannabis poisoning:

  • Cannabis is classified under deliriant cerebral neurotic plant poison.
  • Active principle is usually a fat soluble oleoresin called cannabinol.

Cannabis preparations are:

  • Ganja
  • Charas
  • Bhang
  • Marijuana

Signs and symptoms:

Acute poisoning: Chronic poisoning:
  • Relaxation
  • Drowsiness
  • Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Slurred speech
  • Ataxia
  • Excessive appetite
  • Eating food with great relish
  • Anti motivational syndrome
  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions
  • Run Amok

Treatment:

Acute poisoning cases:

  • Gastric lavage with warm water/emesis.
  • Activated charcoal orally is effective in cases reported within an hour of ingestion.
  • Give strong tea, coffee.
  • Provide artificial respiration, if necessary.
  • Saline purgatives may be helpful.
  • Haloperidol is to be given to control psychotic manifestations if any.
  • Psychotherapy.

Chronic poisoning cases:

  • Gradual withdrawal of the drug.
  • Diazepam for sedation.
  • Haloperidol for psychotic reaction.
  • Psychotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given below picture

choices.text: Diatoms have an extracellular coat composed of magnesium
Acid digestion technique is used to extract diatoms
Presence of diatoms in the femoral bone marrow is an indicator of antemortem inhalation of water

questions.solution:
The extracellular coat of diatoms has silica and not magnesium.

Diatoms are a class of microscopic unicellular algae(Option A) found suspended in most natural waters. Their cell walls are impregnated with silica, chlorophyll, diatomic, and a brown pigment. Diatoms enter the pulmonary circulation during drowning.

The drowning fluid and the particles in it, e.g., diatoms and plankton, pass from the ruptured alveolar wall into lymph channels and pulmonary veins and thus enter the left heart. Only a live body with circulation could transport diatoms from the lungs to the brain, bone marrow, liver and other viscera, and skeletal muscle. They are also found in bile and urine. Bone marrow is highly suitable and reliable.

Isolation of diatoms involves acid digestion of tissue (Option C) - bone marrow, lung, blood, and kidneys with subsequent centrifugation and final residue is aspirated and examined for diatoms, which are birefringent, using dark ground illumination. A water sample is collected at the time of body retrieval in a clean container and the similarity of different species of diatom is compared.

  • The presence of diatoms in the lung, brain, liver, kidneys, and bone marrow of the femur (best site for analysis) or humerus is suggestive proof of antemortem drowning. (Option D)
  • Since diatoms resist putrefaction, the diatom test may have some value in the examination of decomposed bodies.
  • The test is negative in postmortem submersion and in dry drowning. 

Diatoms are ubiquitous in the environment and may enter circulation via the gastrointestinal tract (as contaminants of foods)or via the respiratory tract (which are present in the air). Still, the diatom test is considered the gold standard for the diagnosis of typical drowning.

questions.text: During the examination of an alcohol-intoxicated person, the pupils are constricted, but pinching the skin of the neck leads to transient dilatation of pupils, with a slow return to the original constricted state. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign is called McEwan's sign. In an alcohol-intoxicated patient, the pupils are constricted. But on the application of painful stimuli like pinching or slapping, the pupils slowly dilate. Once the painful stimulus is stopped, the pupils return back to their constricted state.

This is a characteristic finding of ethanol toxicity, seen at blood alcohol concentration levels >300 mg%. It is helpful in differentiating alcoholic coma from other comatose conditions.

The effects of alcohol intoxication at various blood alcohol concentrations are listed below.

Blood alcohol concentration (mg/dL) Effects 
30–50 Impairment of driving and similar skills
50–100 Reduced inhibitions, talkativeness, laughter
100–150 Incoordination, unsteadiness, slurred speech
150–200 Obvious drunkenness, nausea, and ataxia
200–300 Vomiting, stupor
300–350 Stupor , coma, risk of aspirating vomitus
350–450 and above Danger of death from respiratory paralysis

questions.text: All of the following cause traumatic asphyxia, except
questions.solution:
Traumatic asphyxia, or Perthes's syndrome, is a medical emergency caused by an intense compression of the thoracic cage, causing back-flow of blood from the right side of the heart into the veins of the neck and the brain.

Accidental strangulation involves obstruction of the airway or compression of blood vessels in the neck, not the intense thoracic compression required for traumatic asphyxia.

Traumatic asphyxia occurs due to sudden, intense pressure on the chest that obstructs blood flow into the veins of the neck, head, and upper chest, leading to venous congestion, petechiae, and cyanosis. This may occur during road traffic collisions or following collapse of structures such as mine tunnels, or buildings in earthquakes.

Pressure on the chest that restricts movement may also occur if the individual simply gets into, or is placed into, a position in which the free movement of the chest is restricted. This positional asphyxia occurs most commonly in individuals that are rendered immobile through alcohol or drugs and may be seen following restraint in custodial settings.

It may also be seen in the healthy, for example, attempting to climb through a small window to gain access to a property.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER with nausea,vomiting , breathlessness for 2 hours after ingestion of insecticide. On examination there is pin- point pupil and kerosene like smell emitting from the patient. Which of the following is not correct regarding the management of this patient

choices.text: Activated charcoal has no proven therapeutic role
Choline-esterase levels do not have prognostic significance
Atropine is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Organophosphorous poisoning:

  • Most common mode of suicide is by use of insecticide. 
  • Kersone like smell is emitted from the patient.

Symptoms of organophosphorous poisoning:

  • Muscarinic :
    • Emesis, diarrhea.
    • Bronchoconstriction simulating bronchial asthma.
    • Dyspnoea, cough, cyanosis.
    • Bradycardia.
    • Miosis (pin point pupil).
    • Increased salivation, sweating, lacrimation (Chromolacryorrhoea), micturition.
  • Nicotinic :
    • Striated muscle weakness, areflexia.
    • Weakness of respiratory muscles
    • Sympathetic ganglia- Hypertension.
  • CNS:
    • Irritability.
    • Confusion.
    • Fine tremors.

Diagnosis: RBC choline esterase level estimation. It is helpful in diagnosis but has no prognostic significance.

  • Treatment :
    • Decontamination, airway management.
    • Stomach wash- Tap water with or without KMnO4.
    • Activated charcoal shouldnot be used.
    • Atropine is used.
    • Atropine is highly effective in counteracting the peripheral muscarinic effects and antagonize CNS effects at higher doses. But it is not effective against nicotinic actions like respiratory muscle weakess.
    • Oximes can be used early as they have more pronounced action on nicotincic sites.

questions.text: A patient came to the doctor with right sided hearing loss. He was operated for the same. Post surgery the patient notices that his left ear has been operated upon. Which of  the following statements is true?

choices.text: Its a case of professional misconduct
The doctor is punishable under Sec 304 A of IPC
The doctor is punishable under Sec 336 of IPC
Doctrine of medical maloccurence can be applied

questions.solution:
Operating on the wrong side is a case of criminal negligence. The doctor is punishable with imprisonment or fine or both as per provisions of the Sec 336 IPC.

Sec 336 IPC - Act endangering life or personal safety of others - Whoever does any act so rashly or negligently as to endanger human life or the personal safety of others, shall be punished with impris­onment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to two hundred and fifty rupees, or with both.

Sec 337 IPC -  Causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others.

Sec 338 IPC - Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others. In this case, if the patient had loss of hearing in the left ear post surgery then the doctor will be punishable under Sec 338 IPC

Criminal negligence refers to lack of skill and care or gross carelessness during surgery, anesthesia and includes:

  • Operating on the wrong side
  • Leaving surgical accessories in any part of the body
  • Giving wrong blood
  • Performing illegal abortion
  • Injecting drugs in fatal dose

Option A:- Professional misconduct is the infamous conduct in professional respect like :

  • Avoiding consultation
  • Advertising
  • Commercialization
  • Fee splitting

Option B:- Sec 304 A IPC: Causing death by negligence - Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Option D:- Medical maloccurence is the inevitable accident like failure to respond, suffering adverse reaction of drug etc.

Options B and C have been revised in order to make the MCQ factually more correct. Previously the answer for the given scenario was Sec 304 A IPC, which was factually incorrect as the Sec 304 A IPC deals with 'Death because of negligence', and the given scenario talks about the operation on the wrong side without causing any grievous hurt, and this falls under the purview of Sec 336 of IPC.

questions.text:
A pregnant lady was awarded a death sentence for committing murder by the session's court. However, her death sentence was converted to life imprisonment by the High Court. Which of the following sections describes this procedure?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
BNSS Section 456: Commutation of capital sentence on pregnant woman i.e. If a woman sentenced to death is found to be pregnant, the High Court shall commute the sentence to imprisonment for life.

Other options:

Option A: Section 88 of BNS states that miscarriage induced not for the purpose of saving the life/good of the woman, be punished with imprisonment for 3 years. If the woman is “quick with child” the period is extended for 7 years more.

Option B: Section 94 of BNS – concealment of birth and secret disposal of the fetus are punishable.

Option C: BNSS Section 455 deals with the Commutation of death sentence in case of appeal to the Supreme Court.

questions.text: All of the following increases the rate of postmortem cooling except

questions.text: The given sign is most prominent after how many hours of death?
questions.solution:
This picture shows postmortem marbling, i.e. greenish brown or purplish red discoloration of superficial veins. It becomes most prominent after 36-48 hours of death. 

Marbling is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfmeth-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36–48 hours after death.

It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins. Intestinal bacteria infest the venous system, and there is subsequent gas production and hemolysis, which stains the vessel walls. This becomes prominent in the summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.
